Wijze van toepassinga) De verkoop tegen verlaagde prijs aan bepaalde groepen verbruikers was voor de rundvleessector nieuw, daar de prijsverlaging in het kleinhandelsstadium toegepast werd. Dit vergde een ingewikkelde regeling tot bepaling van de rechthebbenden, voor de distributie van en het toezicht op het gebruik van de kortingbonnen.t(l) Bij verordening nr 2930/74 van de Raad van 18 november 1974 zijn soortgelijke vastgesteld voor de sectoren varkensvlees en slachtpluimvee../• - 9^ -Deze verordening is trouwens alleen in Frankrijk en Groot-Brittanie toegepast. In de beide lid-staten zorgden een of meerdere ministeries op het gebied van "sociale zaken", de enige organen die de categorieën rechthebbenden konden aanwijzen, samen met het interventiebureau voor de uitvoering van en de controle op de voorschriften.De belangrijkste controlemaatregelen bestonden erin j- de uitreiking van de bonnen toe to vertrouwen aan de pensioenfondsen(Frankrijk) of aan de diensten van de sociale zaken (Groot-Brittannië);- de ongebruikte bonnen te vernietigen;- de boeken van de betalingscentra na te zien;- de aan de slagers vergoede bonnen na zorgvuldige controle te vernietigen.Bij beschikking nr 75/28/EEG van de Commissie van 19 december 1974 is Frankrijk gemachtigd deze regeling in de Franse Overzeese Departemententoe te passen in de vorm van de verkoop van conserven uit de voorraden van het interventiebureau.b) De lid-staten konden naar eigen goeddunken beslissen hoe zij de informatieve reclamecampagnes zouden voeren.c) De verkoop tegen verlaagde prijs van bepaalde soorten rundvlees enconserven uit interventievoorraden aan bepaalde sociale instellingenen gemeenschappen gesohiedde overeenkomstig het bepaalde in Verorde­ning 216/69 van de Commissie inzake de afzet van door de interventie-bureaus-aangekocht bevroren rundvlees. De voornaamste moeilijkheid wasde invoering van bijzondere maatregelen voor het toezicht op de bestem­ 'H....'.ming van het aldus verkochte vlees. De verordening werd slechts in Italië en België toegepast. *2. Kosten voor het EOGFLa) De kosten voor de verkoop tegen verlaagde prijs aan bepaalde soorten verbruikers worden voor het EOGFL op 36 miljoen r.e. geschat.b)Definancieringvan5 vandeuitgavenvoordeinformatievere­ clamecampagnes betekende voor het EOGFL een extra uitgave Van 2,9 miljoen r.e.•/• -95- •c)DoverkooptegenverlaagdeprijsvanvleeBenconservenuit inter-ventievoorraden bracht een uitgave uit het EOGFL van 1,4 miljoen r.e. met zich»3» Effect op het verbruika) Verkoop tegen verlaagde prijs aan bepaalde groepen verbruikers.In Frankrijk heeft naar schatting 90 "tot 95> van de rechthebbenden en in Groot-Brittanië 85 tot JOfo der rechthebbenden van de rege­ ling gebruik gemaakt.In Frankrijk zelf kon op deze manier 10.000 ton vlees worden afgezet en in de overzeese departementen kon 300 ton conserven worden verkocht. In Groot-Brittanië kon uit studies worden opgemaakt dat het rund- vleesverbruik van alle gezinnen in het eerste kwartaal van 197526$ toegenomen w&s tegenover het eerste kwartaal van 19741 terwijl deze toename in de gepensioneerde gezinnen die voor de steunregeling inaanmerkingkwamen, 6"J/Jobedroeg.b) Het effect van de reclamecampagnes op het rundvleesverbruik kan moeilijk worden beoordeeld.c) In het kader van de verkoop tegen verlaagde prijs van vlees en con­ serven uit interventievoorraden kon in Italië 6.400 ton vlees en in België 150 ton conserven worden afgezet. Dit hoeft niet te betekenen dat het verbruik is toegenomen.DEEL in _ CONCLUSIES EN AANBEVELINGENHoewel geen enkele onregelmatigheid werd gemeld, is het duidelijk dat iedere regeling waarbij produkten tegen voordeliger prijzen aan bepaalde groepen verbruikers (particulieren of gemeenschappen) worden verkocht en/of wlarbij bonnen met een geldwaarde worden gebruikt, risico's inhoudt.De Missie geeft toe dat zulke maatregelen het verbruik kunnen bevorderen. Er is evenwel geen afdoend bewijs geleverd dat het effect van de getroffen maatregelen in een gunstige verhouding staat tot de kosten ervan. De Kissie acht het derhalve wenselijk dat kosten baten-analyses worden gemaakt , zo­ dat de controle vraagstukken en de risico's voor financiële verliezen in het juiste perspectief kunnen worden gezien./• - 96 -Indien, na rijp beraad, in de toekomst dergelijk» regelingen worden ingevoerd, beveelt^de Missie aan :1) de geldigheidsduur ervan te begrenzen, hetgeen het risico voor onregelmatigheden aanzienlijk vermindert;2) bijzondere aandacht te schenken aan de beheers- en controlevoorschrif­ ten (bijvoorbeeld door het aantal gelijktijdig in omloop gebrachte bonnen te beperken, door hun geldigheidBhuur te begrenzen en door geregeld bonnen van andere kleur uit te geven);3) de nodige voorzieningen te treffen om de doeltreffendheid van decontrolemaatregelen op regionaal en nationaal niveau te kunnen beoor­ delen . ! - 97-EINDCONCLUSIES EN AANBEVELINGENIn de voorgaande hoofdstukken heeft de Controlemissie haar aanbevelingen aan de Commissie , die zijn gebaseerd op het onderzoek van de verschillende problemen, van geval tot geval toegelicht.In de inleiding tot dit verslag heeft zij tevens melding gemaakt van de algemene conclusies en aanbevelingen die zijn weergegeven in haar vorige verslagen over zuivelprodukten, olijfolie èn oliehoudende zaden : verbetering van de regeling, verbetering van de samenwerking en van de uitwisseling van gegevens tussen de lid-staten en met de Commissie , ver­ sterking en harmonisering van de sancties, instelling van een regeling voor de terugvordering van onverschuldigd betaalde bedragen, verbetering van de opleiding van de controleurs.De juistheid van deze algemene aanbevelingen werd door het onder­ zoek van de Controlemissie in de rundvleessector ten volle bevestigd, zodat zij met nadruk herhaald moeten worden.Dit rapport wordt afgesloten met de voornaamste algemene conclu­ sies waartoe de Controlemissie bij haar opsporingswerkzaamheden in de sector rundvlees is gekomen. Deze conclusies worden onder twee hoofd­ thema's gerangschikt r- verbetering van de communautaire regeling,- verbetering van de wijze van toepassing van deze regeling.I. VERBETERING VAN DE COMMUNAUTAIRE REGELING.De regeling moet zoveel mogelijk worden vereenvoudigd, op bepaalde punten uniform worden gemaakt en zodanig worden opgezet dat de toe­ passing niet leidt tot economisch niet verantwoorde resultaten. - 98-vereenvoudiging van de regeling,1. Codificatie van de regelingen voor de landbouwsectorGezien het grote aantal verordeningen die in de landbouwsector en met name in de sector rundvlees zijn vastgesteld en gelet op de ingewikkeldheid ervan moet aan codificatie hoge prioriteit worden toegekend.De Controlemissie neemt nota van de aanzienlijke inspanning welke men zich op dit gebied reeds heeft getroost , met name in de sector granen, eieren, pluimvee, varkensvlees en visserij, en is van mening dat' in de overige sectoren soortgelijke werkzaamheden moeten worden ondernomen c.q. worden voortgezet.2» Aanpassing van de regeling aan de materiële mogelijkheden van beheer en controle' De Controlemissie wenst geen oordeel uit te spreken over het econo­ mische belang van de verschillende steunmaatregelen die in de sector rundvlees zijn genomen en heeft de problemen uitfluitend uit het oogpunt van beheer en controle onderzooht. Op grond van de bevindin­ gen waartoe zij aldus is gekomen, beveelt zij aan verordeningen waar­ van de uitvoering een omslachtig beheer vergt en moeilijk te contro­ leren is, zoveel mogelijk te vermijden.. Dezeaanbevelinggeldtconcreetvoorallevormenvansteunverlening in de sector rundvlees.2.i t : Openbare interventie en steun voor de particuliere opslag-'regel zouden beide vormen van interventie, zowel openbare^ ; 7' aankopen door de interventiebureaus als steun voor de particuliere'opslag, betrekking moeten hebben op produkten die door hun aan- biedingsvorm (hele geslachte dieren, voor- en achtervoeten) op betrekkelijk eenvoudige wijze te controleren zijn. De opslag van vlees zonder been en conserven brengt zulke grote problemenin verband met controle en administratief beheer met zich, dathiertoe slechts uit economische noodzaak overgegaan zou mogen . worden. - 99-De Controlemissie heeft voorts vastgesteld dat voor de opslag van interventievlees "buiten de lid-staat waar dit ter interventie vrerdaangeboden, geen uitdrukkelijke voorzieningen in de desbetreffende Gemeenschapsregeling zijn getroffen. De voorschriften ten zake dienen derhalve te worden aangevuld.2.2. Restituties bij uitvoer.Vermeden dient te worden dat op grond van de kenmerken of de aanbiedingsvorm van de produkten verschillende tarieven voor de restituties worden ingevoerd, wanneer het in de praktijk bijna onmogelijk is het vlees bij de fysieke controle aan de vastgestelde onderscheidingscriteria te toetsen of wanneer de regeling niet in dergelijke criteria voorziet.Deze aanbeveling geldt met name voor de volgende onderdelen van do regeling :- onderscheid tussen fokdieren van zuiver ras en: andere dieren(niet voldoende duidelijk gedefinieerd),- percentage zichtbaar inwendig en uitwendig vet (dit onderschei-dingscriterium is trouwens uit de regeling verdwenen)» v64>r dezebeslissing was toetsing ervan vrijwel onmogelijk) ,- differentiatie van de restituties voor delen zonder been naargelangdeze met of zonder vang en schenkel worden aangeboden en ?se aldan niet afzonderlijk verpakt zijn. (hierop valt vrijwel geen controle uit te oefenen onder economisch aanvaardbare voorwaarden).2.3. Premies. Maatregelen van sociale aardDe premieregeling en de maatregelen van sociale aard hebben als gemeenschappelijke kenmerken dat zij betrekking hebben op een groot aantal transacties, dat het administratief beheer uitermate om­ slachtig is en dat controle grote moeilijkheden oplevert en aan­ zienlijke uitgaven vergt. :In sommige gevallen heeft zich een ware "explosie" van het aantalte beheren en controleren transacties voorgedaan, zodat bepaalde lid­ staten zich verplicht hebben gezien in ruime mate een beroep te doen op hulpkrachten die niet voor de uitoefening van controle zijn op­ geleid. - 100 -Cezien deze moeilijkheden, mogen volgens de Controlemissie derge­ lijke maatregelen eerst worden getroffen of gehandhaafd, na een kosten-batenanalyse, zodat alle betrokken factoren - economische aspecten, controlevraagstukken en gevaar voor onregelmatigheden - tegen elkaar kunnen worden afgewogen.De instanties van de Gemeenschap moeten zich er ook van vergewissen dat vooral bij de aanvang nauwlettend wordt nagegaan, hoe deze regelingen werken, zodat onvolkomenheden snel aan het licht gebracht en verholpen kunnen worden.Streven naar uniforme regelingenDe Controlemissie heeft vastgesteld dat grote moeilijkheden voort­ vloeien uit het feit dat binnen de Gemeenschap op ëen zelfde terrein verschillende regelingen naast elkaar bestaan of uit het feit dat de lid-staten wordt toegestaan voor een zelfde regeling verschillende uitvoeringsbepalingen vast te stellen.1 . Over het algemeen zouden door de instelling van een uniforme rege­ ling voor het hele grondgebied van de Gemeenschap talrijke moeilijk­ heden bij de toepassing ervan worden voorkomen. ,Indien evenwel om economische redenen, zoals het geval lijkt te zijn voor het premiestelsel, verschillende regelingen moeten worden in­ gesteld, dient ervoor te worden gezorgd dat het naast elkaar bestaan van deze regelingen geen extra moeilijkheden voor de controle op­ levert en het gevaar voor onregelmatigheden niet vergroot.i ..2. Bij een bepaalde verordening (premie voor het slachten van bepaalde . volwassen runderen) is de lid-staten een zekere vrijheid gelaten ten aanzien van de wijze van toepassing (toekenning van de premie bij de. J eerste verkoop van het rund ) dan wel bij het slachten; uiteenlopende bepalingen om te voorkomen dat een dier waarvoor de premie is betaald voor' interventie wordt aangeboden).De Controlemissie is van oordeel dat een meer uniforme regeling de controle zou hebben vergemakkelijkt. " - 101 -C. Voorkoming van economisch niet verantwoorde resultaten1» De Controlemissie heeft' opnieuw (l) vastgesteld dat er verschillen bestaan in de tarieven voor de te heffen en toe te kennen monetaire compenserendebedragenencompenserendebedragen"toetreding" o.a. naar gelang van de aanbiedingsvorm of de mate waarin de produkten bewerkt zijn. Deze verschillen zijn niet steeds economisch verantwoord en hebben tot kunstmatige handelsstromen geleid, die het EOGFL veel geld hebben gekost en waaruit tevens is gebleken dat het stelsel van compenserende bedragen geen neutrale factor vormt ten aanzien van de handelsstromen .iPro memorie worden hier enkele voorbeelden uit de voorgaande hoofd­ stukken herhaald :- uiteenlopende tarieven voor de monetaire compenserende bedragen als gevolg van de toepassing van coëfficiënten (ten. aanzien van hele. geslachtedieren,voor6enachtervoeten,delenyangeslachtedieren, enz...) die de werkelijke kosten van bewerking niet steeds juist weergaven , •- wijze waarop de invloed wordt berekend van het douanerecht als element ter correctie van het compenserende bedrag "toetreding" in het handels­ verkeer tussen de lid-staten op het continent enerzijds en Groot- Brittannië en Ierland anderzijds*2. De Controle missie doet de volgende aanbeveling :2é1 »2.2.De vaststelling van de tarieven door de Commissie en de comités van ιbeheer moet worden voorafgegaan door een nog grondiger onderzoekvan het vraagstuk ten einde de economische invloed van de voorgenomen maatregelen te bepalen;Voor het intracommunautaire handelsverkeer moet principieel eensymmetrie bestaan tussen de monetaire compenserende bedragen en . de compenserende bedragen "toetreding" die worden toegekend bij-/·(l) De Controlemissie heeft dit probleem reeds behandeld in haar verslag over zuivelprodukten; het ging toen om "magere" en "vette" yoghurt. - 102invoer en geheven bij uitvoer of vice-versa, wanneer blijkt dateen produkt achtereenvolgens wordt ingevoerd en uitgevoerd zonder dat het in de economische kringloop van de betrokken lid-staat wordt opgenomen en voor zover deze symmetrie de handelaar geen voordelen brengt ." Dit zou een remmend effect hebben op de speculatieve trans­ acties, o.a. die van het zogenaamde "rundvleescarrousel"-type;2.3. De lid-staten moeten in staat worden gesteld op te treden tegen speculatieve transacties die niet stroken met dé economische doel­ einden van de regeling. Op korte termijn zou dit doel kunnen worden bereikt door toepassing van de theorie van het "rechtsmisbruik" op om financiële steun te weigeren in alle gevallen van deze aard waarin dit bij de huidige stand van de voorschriften mogelijk is.De toepassing van deze theorie in concrete gevallen zal evenwel af­ hangen van de mogelijkheid aan te komen dat de betrokken transactie niet in overeenstemming is met de doelstellingen van de regeling, waardoor de werkingssfeer ervan zou worden beperkt.. Op langere termijn biedt een Gemeenschapsregeling waarschijnlijk de beste oplossing om dit doel te bereiken. Het lijkt dan ook stelsel- ' matig en duidelijk de toepassingsvoorwaarden van ieder Gemeenschaps- besluit met finajiciële gevolgen te preciseren in het licht van het economische doel. Dit wordt impliciet gesuggereerd in de "resolutie van de Raad betreffende krachtiger maatregelen ter voorkoming en vervolging van onregelmatigheden in het kader van de financiering van het gemeenschappelijk landbouwbeleid" (l) In deze resolutie worden de instellingen van de Gemeenschappen namelijk door de Raad verzocht "zo krachtig mogelijk op te 'treden ten einde te waarborgen dat in de besluiten van de Gemeenschap verlening van financiële steun is uit­ gesloten- voor fictieve transacties,-'wanneer de aanwending van de gesubsidieerde produkten duidelijk,in strijd is met de bedoelingen van de besluiten van de Gemeenschap» voor zover deze bedoelingen daarin zijn vermeld".O ) PB n° C 298 van 30 december 1975 1.1 .-wat de betrekkingen tussen de lid-staten aangaat zijn een aantal onvolkomenheden aan het licht gekomen. Het betreft met name infor­ matie over de soorten documenten die worden afgegeven en over de indevelschillendelid-statengebruiktestempels(b.v.douane- en veterinaire stempels) en merktekens ter identificatie (premie­ regeling). Zij is derhalve van mening dat iedere 'onvolkomenheid in de beoordeling van de financiële gevolgen van zulke maatregelen op het vlak van de Gemeenschap kans op onregelmatigheden ten nadele- 103 -In het algemeen is de Controlemissie van mening dat do in de punten A, B en C vermelde doelstellingen gemakkelijker zouden kunnen worden "bereikt indien de vertegenwoordigers van de controle-organen actiever zouden meewerken aan het opstellen van de verordeningen.VERBETERING VAN DB WIJZE VAN TOEPASSING VAN DE REGELINGAt Informatie en samenwerking1 • Tussen de lid--staten onderling en tussen de lid-staten en de Commissiev van de Gemeenschap oplevert. Met betrekking tot het verstrekken van mededelingen aan de.■Commissie, acht de Controlemissie het onderscheid dat wordt gemaakt tussen onregelmatigheden die meeruitgaven van het EOGFL-Garantie met zich brengen en onregelmatigheden die het derven van eigen inkomsten tot gevolg hebben, tamelijk kunst­ matig, meer in het bijzonder door de invoering van het stelsel van monetaire compenserende bedragen die geboekt moeten worden ofwel in het kader van de eigen middelen, ofwel in het kadervan de verrichtingen van het EOGFL-Garantie.(cf bijlage 3 be­ treffende de boeking van de monetaire compenserende bedragen en van de compenserende toetredingsbedragen.)Het is verder duidelijk dat het ontduiken van heffingen bij invoer van produkten uit derde landen in de Gemeenschap een ver­ slechtering van de markttoestand in de Gemeenschap en een toenamevan de steunuitgaven ten laste van het EOGFL-Garantie tot gevolg kan hebben.Daarom beveelt de Controlemissie aan een soortgelijke regeling als bedoeld in Verordening 283/72 ook voor de eigen middelen inte voeren of de werkingssfeer van Verordening 283/72 tot de eigen middelen uit te breiden.Samenwerking binnen de bepaalde tran­ sacties (bijvoorbeeld aankopen door het interventiebureau) of met de uitvoering van zogenaamde "routine"-contrOles (b.v. gewichts­ controles) zou moeten worden uitgebreid.De wesgapparatuur zou moeten worden gemoderniseerd on regelmatig aan een nauwgezette controle moeten worden onderworpen*Het bestuderen van de statistische indicatoren met betrekking tot de Verbeterinft vein de controls1. Oplossingen voor sommigc structurele onvolkomenheden2» Onafhankelijke controlesDe Controlemissie is van oordeel dat in bepaalde lid-staten de externe controle op de transacties van de interventiebureaus, die volkomen buiten deze interventiebureaus om geschiedt , intensiever zou moeten worden toegepast.3» Verscherping van bepaalde specifieke controlesDe Controlemissie heeft er in de voorafgaande hoofdstukken reeds herhaaldelijk op gewezen dat, gezien de bestaande mogelijkheden inzake onregelmatigheden, een bijzonder strenge controle zou moeten worden toegepast op :- de voorraadadministratie, - het uitbenen en- in het voorkomende geval de conservenfabricage../. Meer bepaald voor wat de openbare opslag betreft wijst de Controle- missie nogmaald op het belang dat zij hecht aan de opstelling van systematische programma's inzake voorraadcontrole enerzijds, en aan de algemene toepassing van het principe dat de koelhuizen financiële verantwoordelijkheid dragen voor de hun toevertrouwde voorraden ander­ zijds. Deze verantwoordelijkheid zou formeel moeten worden vastgelegd in het kader van contracten.Daarnaast dient de nadruk te worden gelegd op het belang van de controle op de uitvoertransacties , voor zover deze transacties voor toekenning van financiële voordelen in aanmerking komen. Traditioneel oefenden de douanediensten namelijk vooral toezicht uit op de invoertransacties.Harmonisatie van de procedures ■ ~iDe Controlemissie heeft geoonstateerd dat het bestaan van verschillende procedures binnen de Gemeenschap de controle moeilijker maakt en onregel­ matigheden in de hand werkt.Dit geldt met name voor :- do vereenvoudigde douaneprocedure voor het rechtstreekse handels­ verkeer tussen twee lid-staten, aangezien de combinatie van deze procedure met die voor het communautaire douanevervoer een aantal handelaren in staat heeft gesteld onregelmatige transacties te ver­ richten;- de verscheidenheid aan markeersystemen gebruikt in de verschillende lid-Gtaten .De Controlemissie adviseert de Commissie en de lid-staten overleg teplegen ten einde tot de geleidelijke eenmaking van deze procedures te komen . - 10? -ITenslotte bereiken de Controlemissie steeds meer alarmerende berichtenover onregelmatig eden op het gebied van het communautaire douanever- voer, die met name zouden worden gepleegd door valse of vervalste T1 en T2-documenten te gebruiken.De groep wijst voorlopig slechts nair de reeds in hoofdstuk III gedane aanbevelingen (zie punt E, blz. 55 ) doch behoudt zich voor het vraagstuk grondiger te onderzoeken en in het volgende verslag over de wijnsector nadere aanbevelingen te formuleren.^,anc^ DuitslandBeigiëltenejtiark9nFrankrijklerlandInterventiebureauRegeling handelsverkeer Hauptzollamt Hamburg-JonasSamburgBundeskasse "bei der OberfinanzdirektionBETMLORGANKV VOOR HBT BEHF5VAN DS RUNDVLESSMARKTF!î îmiiEinfuhr– und Vorratsstell© ftir SchlachtviehFleisch und Fleischerzeugnisse Frankfurt/MainBundesamt für Ernährung (vanaf 1.7.1.976) Frankfurfc/mainBelgische dienst voor Bedrijfsleven en Land­ bouw (BDBL),Trierstraat, 82, 1040-BrusselDirektoratet for Markedsordningerne EF–DirektoratetTorvegade 2, DK 1400 KøbenhavnOffice Nationale Interprofessionnel duBétail et de la Viande (ONIBSV) 8-10, bd de VaugirardParis 75733DepartmentofAgriculture&, Fisheries Upper Merrion StreetDublin 2 .Azienda di Stato per gli Interventi nel Mercato Agricolo (AIKA)Via Palestro, 800185 Roma*•«_ <tauburg(ordonnateur). It was made clear , however that in studying this particular sector it ought to be possible to examine, in depth, problems concerning the system of compensatory amounts and stock control .The main reason why the Committee chose beef and veal is the substantial growth in expenditure by the Guarantee Section in this sector (as shown inthe diagrams below), and, in particular, the considerable additional expenditure on the various new systems of premiums which have been intro­ duced as part of the organization of the beef and veal market.Furthermore, the cases of fraud and speculative deflections of trade that have come to light recently encouraged the Committee to examine the circumstances and seek ways of remedying the si fcration. 1000 mill.UA - UC - REAide à 1 exportation (restitutions )Aid to exports (refunds)ErstattungenAiuto ali esportazione (restituzioni )Restituties rundvlees500mill. The object of the exercise was to enable the Members of the Committee to take a look at the practicalarrangements for implementing the intervention system, the trade arrange­ ments and the system of premiums.* **The Special Committee of Inquiry takes the opportunity provided by this report to recall the conclusions and general recommendations formulated in previous reports, the action taken subsequently and the other work carried out by Community institutions which could contribute to more effective prevention of irregularities and better protection of Community funds.As a first step the Committee advocated improving the Community milesby introducing greater precision and by adapting those provisions whichhave proved difficult to apply. It stressed the advantage of greater co­operation between administrations, between Member States and betweenMember States and the Commission and the need to improve certain controlprocedures. It suggested that the penalties for infringements be increasedand the methods of recovering sums wrongly paid be improved. Finally it stressed the importance of improving the training of staff responsible forcarrying out checks.Various discussions and opinions stemmed from the examination of these reports by the Commission, the Parliament and the Council. -5-The European Parliament approved the conclusions reached by the Committeein its previous reports and added some general comments , notably oi the need for setting up a European Court of Auditors (Doc. EP No. 40 157 and 41 708).The Council concluded the examination of the first two reports of the1 Committee by adopting a: "Resolution on stricter prevention of and proceedingsagainst irregularities in the financing of the common agricultural policy" (OJ C 298 of 30 December 1975)*In this Resolution the Council firstly calls on the Member States and the Commission to put the conclusions and recommendations of the Committee into practice. Secondly the Council hopes in particular that financial support will be granted only to those economic operations which are carried out ~in lino with the objectives of the Community rules in so far as theseobjectives are set out in Community acts. •)The Council also adopted the "Directive on mutual assistance for the recovery of claims resulting from operations forming part of the systemof financing the European Agricultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund andof the agricultural levies and customs duties" (OJ L 73 of 19 March 1976).Little progress has been made, however, in the Private storage aid will be dealt with in Chapter II.SECTION I - THE RULES. A. The guide priceThe basic Regulation 805/63 on the common organization of the market in beef and veal is based on the concept of a "guide price", which may be definedas the price which it is hoped to attain on average on the Community market for all the quantities marketed during a given marketing year. Two guide prices are fired before 1 August each year for the marketing year beginning in the following year, one for calves and the other for adult bovine animals. Pure-bred breeding animals are not covered by the organization of the market.On the internal market of the Community, the guide price is intended toencourage production without leading to the formation of structural sur­pluses , and servos as a reference in the public buying-in policy , since the intervention price is fixed as a percentage of the fevide pri^° - It is also used in calculating the Community protection against importB from non-as last amended by Regulation 3083/75} Regula>.ion\^622/74, as amended by Regulation 3183/74 (l))»/•For the rules on the financing of intervention expenditure : Council Regulation 2305/70, as amended by Regulation 1174/75 Intervention measures may be applied .. when prices on theCommunity market cease to remunerate production at a level close to the guide price. As the rules are at present, there can "be no intervention inrespect of veal .Three "types of intervention in the form of public buying-in are providedfor, only two of which depend on the level of prices on the Community market,calculated on the basis of prices recorded on the representative markets of each Member State .(a) Where the Community market price for adult bovine animals is lees than98 % of the guide price and simultaneously the market price in a certain region is less than 93 of the guide price, intervention measures may bo taken in the regions concerned.(b) V/here the Community market price is less than 93 of the guide price, intervention is automatic throughout the Community.(c) There is a system of "permanent'* intervention, which is unrelated to the levels mentioned above. Introduced by the Council on 20 December 1972, itsaim was "to enable operators to offer certain high quality meat at anytime, whatever the Community market price, and to receive 93 $ of the guide price. This measure, therefore assured breeders of a kind of minimum guaranteed price , as is the case in other sectors .The obligation on intervention agencies to buy was howevermodified for the 1976/77 marketing year to avoid encouraging production whichwould only be destined for intervention. Council Regulation No. 568/76 of 15 March 1^76 provides in efftect that if the price recorded on the representative marketsof a Member State or of a region of a Member State is not less than 95 % of••*/••• * ^ Derogations? for the 1975/76 marketing year the intervention price was fixedthe guide price (Regulation 463/ 75 ) for theat 90.42 % instead of 93 % of1976/77 marketing year it was fixed at 90 % of the ginde price.■ - 10 -the guide price during a certain period the "permanent" intervention measures may be totally or partially suspended in the Member State or rcgioiy concerned .2. Innervation in £racticeBuying in by the intervention agency is governed by three essential require­ ments :• - to ensure effective market support,- to facilitate the disposal of goods on their removal from storage, - to restrict the financial burden on the Community.Therefore, only meat of certain qualities and certain cuts may be bought in. Checking for compliance with these standards must be carried out by the inter­ vention agency at the time of buying in (checking of weight, quality and origin of the meat offered and veterinary checks) In addition, the intervention centres must be so chosen by Member States that the operations of intake and, where appropriate, slaughtering and freezing may be carried out under satis­ factory technical conditions.Since the buying-in prices cr® fixed by the Commission according to quality (a maximum and a minimum price per quality), buying in entails classificationof the meat offered by reference to national scales for the grading of carcases.On account of the saturation of public storage facilities, the Community hashad to defray, in addition to the storage costs as such, part of the cost of 1111 ■■■!•* y ■transporting (Council Regulation 1729/74) and processing the meat stored. The costs involved are the additional transport costs incurred by operators whose meat could not be accepted by one of the five nearest intervention centres and the costs of processing either by boning (Regulation 1315/74, repealed by Regulation 2630/75)' or Vy "the manufacture of preserved products(Regulation 1295/74^^)* For the disposal of frozen beef from public stocks••«/é••Since the introduction of the premium systems (orderly marketing premium and premium for producers of bovine animals), the intervention agency must check when meat is bought in whether it comes from animals on which a premium hasbeen paid. In principle the meat cannot be bought in in such case. If, by way of derogation from this rule, such meat is bought in, the intervention agency mustdemand that the seller refund the premium.(2) :v ' Regb"! ation lapsed on 6 April 1975^ Regulation lapsed on 23 May 1975 - 11 -(Council Regulation 9S/«9 and Commission Regulation 216/69) the selling prices are either pre-set or determined "by means of a tendering procedure. It should be noted that , although for buying in there is a scale of pricesfor the various qualities of carcase, this is not necessarily re­ flected in the fixing of the selling prices , since the price range for frozen meat is much narrower than for fresh meat.In order to facilitate the disposal of public stocks and, to encourage meat consumption, two measures were taken :- sale at reduced prices of certain beef and veal end preserves thereof to certain institutions and bodies of a social character (Co-mnission Regulation 2035/74)}- sale of beef and veal at reduced prices to certain categories of consumer (Council Regulation 1856/74 ).These measures will be dealt with in Chapter VI of this report.SECTION II - ANALYSIS OF IRREGULARITIES AND PROBLEMS IN ADMINISTERING THE INTERVENTION SYSTEMPew irregularities have been discovered. However, the checks which would enable them to be detected are sometimes inadequate.A. Irregularities1. Only one serious irregularity has been found and reported to the Commission. It concerns the check weighting of carcases offered for intervention . In the case in point the declared weight of the carcases , which was registered by the intervention agency and used as the basis for^ payment , was 10$ above their actual weight .The irregularity was discovered when the hot weight of carcases, which is recorded for factory purposes, was compared with the cold weight which is 1I !•^used as tho basis for sale to the intervention agency. It was found thatinstead of being lower than the hot weight the cold weight was recorded as being higher and it appeared that the cold weight had been inflated by about 10 %.i The intervention centre in this case was located in the factory offering ' the meat to intervention and the weighing was carried out on the factoryscales. The explanation suggested for the recording of inflated weights was that these .scales had been tampered with. While this may be a possible explanation of how the fraud was perpetrated it is disturbing to find that an irregularity of this magnitude, which was based on fraudulent misrepre­ sentation of weight , could go undetected for a period of nine months and it leaves the Committee in some considerable doubt as to the effectiveness of the supervision exercised at this factory.2. Several cases of shortfall in public intervention stocks have been recorded They are not necessarily due to irregularities. In all cases the ware­houses concerned were held financially responsible*B. Deficiencies in checking1. In£ernal_ajid_external supervision of_the__ojn>erations3 carried ou£ by_the •» jinterven;tion_agenc^esThere are several types of supervision of the operations carried out by intervention agencies.The intervention agencies have introduced various internal procedures for the supervision of operations for which they are responsible (mainly buying in and storage). In some Member States, within the intervention•*•/#• ^ -13-agency itself or the peripheral organizations responsible for the actual execution of the operations a specialized corps of inspectors has been set up to carry out internal supervision of all operations.There is also a measure of external supervision, usually provided by an audit body or other independent organization.However, it would seem that iextemal supervision could be stepped, up in some Member States .Checks__at the time_of bujring_inThe controls of a qualitative nature (origin, quality, health) are car­ ried out satisfactorily and may lead to the refusal of meat by the inter­ vention agency.It has been established, however, that in one respect some inter­vention agencies do not carry out the checks required by the rules i this is where an intervention agency accepts meat from animals on which a premium has been paid at the time of their initial marketing or at the time of slaughter.In principle, such meat must be identified so that either it can be refused by the intervention agency or the seller can be required to refund the premium .It should be noted that these checks are required even in Member States which do not apply the premium system, since their intervention agencies may buy in meat from animals originating in other Member States which grant the premium. It must be admitted, however, that in this case the originof the meat offered for intervention is difficult to detect since it bears only the stamp of the slaughterhouse in the country where it is offeredfor intervention.The absence of strict controls may .have lead to the operator benefiting both from the premium and from the normal buying in price paid by the inter­vention agency , contrary to the rules in . force and a source of undue expenditure for the EAGGP. 3 .Some Member States have solved this problem by systematically making the re<ruiro& deduction from tho buying in prioo* on the assumption that all meat offered to the intervention agency comes from animals on which a premium had been paid.It should be noted that under the new system of slaughter premiums applicablein the 1976/77 marketing year it is still prohibited to combine the premiumand the normal intervention price in the Member State that grants the premium (Council Regulation 797/76 of 6 April 1976, Article 2)j from now on Member States that do not apply the new premium system may in no case buy inderived from categories of animal eligible for the premium in a Member Statewhich applies the system (Commission Regulation 803/76 of 7 April 1976).Thus the intervention agencies are still under an obligation to exercise control .Inadequate_or obsolete weighing equipmentOn their field visits the Committee noted that equipment used to weigh live animals (in ports, at the time of export) or carcases (at the time of buying in or talcing into storage) did not record the weight as accurately as might be wished. Weighing* machines that automatically print out the weight on a ticket are highly desirable .Supervision of storage operationsCommunity miles impose several obligations on Member States with respect to stock accounting and the supervision of storage conditions.(a) Control of quantities in store. The Member States must notify the Commission of the products and quantities in store at the end of each month as a result ofbuying in. giving the address and the place of storage (Regulation I896/73, Article 12).4 .\- 14 -• •/• ( * - .15 -This obligation entails :- continuous stock accounting "by the central departments of the intervention agency,- periodic comparisons between these stock accounts and those kept "by each store,- physical checks to verify that the accounting stocks agree with the actual stocks .In practice , the first requirement is usually met , although weaknesses haveappeared in the " analysis of the central accounts by store . Furthermore the various sets of accounts are not always systematically compared.Lastly, on-the-spot stocktaking is generally considered to be too time-consuming and too costly and so is seldom carried out . However , on field visits the Committee was able to observe that physical possibilities of inspecting stocks largely depended on the system adopted for recording the lots as they were placed in storage. In, particular, the Committee had the opportunity to study a carefully pre­ pared system of identifying the lots placed in storage, under which the stock accounting was easy to follow and which also facilitated physical stocktaking .(b) Supervision of storage conditionsMember States must take all measures necessary to ensure the satisfactory preservation of the stored products (Regulation IO96/73, Article 4 (2)).The public storage of meat taken over by the intervention agency is frequent­ly entrusted to private storage firms. Member States must select the 'stores by reference to their ability to supply the necessary services and must reserve the right to carry out periodic checks of physicalstorage conditions.No irregularities in this respect were brought to the Committee's attention. It was nevertheless established that one intervention agency had received complaints from purchasers of intervention meat regarding the state of preservation of the meat. \ 'This loavoe some doubt regarding tho existence or effectiveness jbf the checks carried out at stores.5« Processing of meat taken in by the intervention agencyThe supervision of processing operations raises a delicate problemin that only permanent supervision of processing could provide all the requisite guarantees that processors were meeting their obligations.(a) Boning *Community rules specify in detail the physical conditions under which boning must take place . These must be inserted in the contracts concluded between the intervention agency and the cutting plants. These conditions deal in particular with the temperatureof the plant , the trimming and packaging of cuts and the timetable for carrying out the work.It was found in the course of on-the-spot checks by the Commission services that the Burrounding temperature was not alwayB checked (lack of recording thermometer).The addition, one intervention agency found several cases where the labelling of boxes of boned cuts did not correspond to their actual contents . Incorrect labelling may conceal an irregularity , such as the misappropriation of certain cuts by the cutting plant.(b) Processing into preserved productsProcessing into preserved products is carried out by private undertakings. The intervention agency must reserve the right toexercise constant supervision of this activity and verify the quality of manufacture of' the processed products before taking them in .In practice , spot checks ar,e carried out a posteriori in the form of analyses of manufacturing samples. This procedure does not make- 16 -*/ - 17 -it possible to determine whether the processors have met all their obligations and in particular whether the meat supplied by theintervention agency was used in itB entirety and. exclusively in the manufacture of preserved products.The imperfect nature of checking by means of chemical analysis of the! preserved meat will be dealt with later in connection with the export \checks on preserved meat qualifying for refunds which vary according to the meat content .SECTION III - IMPERFECTIONS AND PROBLEMS IN APPLYING THE RULES1. Public intervention stocks stored b.y a Member State outside its ov;n territorySeveral Member States , in order to store their public intervention stocks , make use or have in the past made use of storage capacity available either in another Member State or a non-memb©'r country.This practice, which has become necessary in particular since 1974 because of the saturation of storage capacity in certain Member States, has grown up without any well-defined legal basis. The present rulesdo not expressly provide for stocks to be held abroad.The transfer of stocks abroad has therefore taken place on ad hocterms determined by each Member State which has given rise to legal difficulties (customs status of goods stored abroad, method ofapplying the system of compensatory amounts) and practical difficulties(checkingof these stocks, cost of storage and quality of the services provided by the private storers).(a) Customs treatment appliedIn some cases the meat was dispatched under temp- rr r- export arrangements and sometimes, when there wre no such arrangements in the Member State concerned , the meat was treated as an ordinary export . - 18 -Likewise | storage in the country of destination has "been carried out under customs procedure that can vary from one Member State to another: some Member States have applied the bonded warehouse Eystem, whereas one Member State has always considered intervention: yrneat'thuGstoredinitsterritorytobeinfreecirculation*-(b) Application of the system of compensatory amountsAt the time of export the Member States concerned have not applied the monetary and accession compensatory amounts either on export ofthe goods from their territory or on entry to the country of storage*According to the Member States, the suspension of these amounts resulted either from the customs treatment chosen (temporary exportation, bonded warehouse) or from the view that the exportation of goods did not constitute a commercial transaction.tThe amounts were eventually applied, case by case and according to final destination, when the meat was removed from store followingits resale. The amounts were fixed by reference to the date of offtake .(c) Stock control procedures':11The fact of storing goods abroad does not release the Member State concerned from the obligation to supervise the stocks.– In all cases the Member State responsible for the stocks must by on-the-spot checks ascertain the presence and state of preservation of the meat.In practice, these visits seem to have been all too rare.- In caseB where meat is stocked under the bonded warehouse system, inspections are made by customs officials. But since these inspections relate only to quantities and the non-substitution ofgoods, they cannot replace inspections by the Member State responsibl for the stocks.Therefore , both types of inspection should be carried out where appropriate and this has not always been done.•••/••• (d) Financial implicationsThe additional costs incurred for this type of storage must not be underestimated.These are the transport costs and , where appropria+e , the offtakeand rointake costs, which are "borne "by the Guarantee Section of the EAGGP on a flate-rate basis. Where the transfer of meat held by the intervention agency is involved, there is no limit on the distance forwhich transport costs are reimbursed.However, for this operation to be carried out two conditions must be satisfied : the transfer must have become necessary and must be carried out after authorization in accordance with the Management Committee procedure.Lastly, one intervention agency found that the costs of storage abroad were higher than the rate currently charged on its own territory, while the services were of poorer quality than those habitually afforded by cold stores in its own country. vComplaints to the intervention agency on the part of purchasersWhere frozen meat is sold by the intervention agency the rules (Commission Regulation 216/69, Articles 3, 4» 8 and 9) provide that :(a) the intervention agency is to make the necessary arrangements to permit those concerned to inspect the products for sale before making their bids ;(b) that a bid submitted by the purchaser to the intervention agency for the purchase of frozen meat is not valid unless '■.* is accompanied by a statement in which the bidder agrees to forego anj claim as to the q-JCi!! it,/ or - U.ri5.iic:;; ~ thj i-tj u .;l .... i ... ...y be assigned to him . - 20 -In practice, "these provisions have certain disadvantages:- Firstly, in the cane of boned meat certain defects cannot "be detected in the frozen state. Prior examination of the goods "by the purchasers docsnot provide them with a real guarantee unless it is carried out on samples which are considered to "be representative of the lot to lie assigned and vrhichhavefirstbeenthawed butsuchconditionsarenotalwaysfulfilled.'- Secondly, the a priori exclusion of any claims has not in practice prevented such claims from being made and from being investigated by the intervention agency concerned.The individual solutions applied to each case by the authorities concerned havenot occasioned any expenditure for the EAGGF. Nevertheless, there issomething to be learned from this situation in that such complaints may point up errors of classification at the time of buying in, defects in preservation methods, or even opportunities for substitution during storage.ι.V3. Harmonization of the neat /grading 3.ystcms used by the Member StatesEach Member State uses a system of grading carcases and quarters xvhich, although based on uniform criteria (age, weight, conformation and degree of fattening), leads to the creation of a scale of quality which is not transferable from one Member State to another.Grading depends partly on the breed of the animals, which may explain the specific nature of each national grading system. On the other hand, some categories do not exist in certain Member States simply because they correspond to a particular type of cut which the other States do not use (e.g. Pistola cut).The results, of this are that :\– it is necessary to fix a multitude of buying-in prices, which complicatesthe administration of the common agricultural policy, *– it is impossible for operators to malcta valid comparisons between the . quality of meat from different Member States ,– there are difficulties in marketing from one Member State to another and restrictions on competition. - 21 -The aim should be to move towards a single grading system.4» Fixing of prices "by category on buying in and on regale "by the intervention agencyTho number of categories used for fixing the buying-in prices and the selling prices for meat held "by the intervention agencies are not the same*At the time of resale , certain qualities , to which different buying>-in pricc3 were applied, are amalgamated and the meat sold at a single average price.Although this system is acceptable for tho resale of forequarters, whichare mainly intended for the processing industry , the Committee "believes that differences in quality should be respected at least in the case of hind­ quarters , so that a post-check can "be carried out , on resale , of tho grading which was effected at the time of "buying in.5. Application of the permanent intervention systemThe introduction "by the Council of the permanent intervention system was intended to afford producers a true price guarantee by giving them theopportunity of offering meat for intervention whatever the level of prices recorded on the market.Application of the system seems to have led to excesses. In one country which is conspicuous for its deficit , the intervention agency had to un­dertake buying in while the market prices were much higher than the inter­ vention prices.As regards the economics of the situation, possible explanations include :– in a country with a deficit and extremely dependent on external influences, market prices are subject to frequent fluctuations. It may be assumed,~therefore, that producers will use the intervention system to avoid accepting a lower price on occasion:c.v^r:^,c pric^u r J-.rbr ü•. . in the Momber State conoerned can, while being clearly above the intervention purchasing price, mask a much lower purchasing price level in certain regions.•••/••* Tho Committee has been unable to compare these' explanations with the realities of the eituation. Nevertheless it considers that the system of permanent intervention as practised until the end of the 1975/76 marketing year tended to discourage commercial enterprise on the part of producers.The Committee is therefore in favour of the reiform of the system set forth «« /■ M •• –yi"\/in Council Regulation No 568/76, which provides that permanent interventionmeasures can be totally or partially suspended in a Member State or region when the price recorded on the representative market or markets of that Member State or region is not less than 957° of the guide price for a certain period .Buying in of meat from anim.ils on which premiums have been paidRules have been laid down governing the buying in for intervention of meat from animals on which a premium has been paid* During the 1974/75 and 1975/76 marketing years such buying in was in principle prohibited. Member States could, however, derogate from this prohibition provided the premium was repaid.This provision , which airnd at preventing unnecessary expenditure by the EAGGP in respect of the same animal, w® difficult to apply, particularly where the animals ware not slaughtered in the Member State grant­ing the premium, In; practice it meant that Member States had to be able to determine the origin of the meat offered (animals receiving a premium or notin another Member State), but this information wasnot necessarily available, particularly if the meat in question had not been specially marked.The^system applicable in the 1976/77 marketing year (deduction of the premium in the case of Member States applying the premium, prohibition on buying in in the case of the other Member States) calls for inspections to be carried out by all Member States.It is,however, simpler in that live animals which are the subject of intra^- Community trade are no longer entitled to the premium. Consequently, meat fromanimals slaughtered in a Member State other than the one granting the premium, which could cause identification problems, is' no longer affected by the prohibition on buying in. This prohibition on buying in now relates only tomeat exported by the Member State granting the premium, the origin of which is easily identifiable from the veterinary stamp placed on the meat at the elaugtherhouse .Timetable for application of Community decisionsThe Member States have sometimes experienced difficulties in meeting the dead­ lines for applying certain Community decisions.Under Commission Regulation 1295/74 of .22 May 1974 on the processing (into preserved products) of beef bought in by intervention agencies, the deadline for the completion of such operations was 3 August 1974. Other regulations subsequently extended the validity of that Regulation.Nevertheless, the relatively short period allowed in the first instance forced the< intervention agencies to act in haste, which could only affect adversely the conditions under which contracts with the manufacturers were concluded and performed...*'SECTION IV - RECOMMENDATIONSA. Weighingequipmentandoperationsa) Itisessentialthatweighingequipmentbereplacedifobsoleteand that it be regularly inspected in all establishments, whether public or private, where weight certification is carried out.b) Weighingoperationsinconnectionwithpurchasesbyintervention agencies must always be supervised.B. Principles of stock control StocktakingThe Committee has carefully considered the question of stocktaking of bee£ purchased by intervention agencies and held in cold stores by them. It notes that the practice in regard to stocktaking* varies in effective­ ness between the Member States, and 'considers tha.t control exercised by the intervention agency in this area could be iruvov'A• TV rv----?ttec fully realises that there are particular diffi . lties in connection with stocktaking in the beef sector due to such factors as the quantities involved, the conditions under which beef must be stored (low temperature) and tho location of tho cold stores /which may be situated in another Member State or in a third country.It also recognises that a certain measure of control exists in come MemberStates whereby the cold store must enter into a contract to accept legalresponsibility for quantities delivered into store and would therefore beheld liable to make good any deficiencies.I iNevertheless tho Committee considers that an essential element in the con­ trol of intervention stocks should be a systematic programme of stock­taking and reconciliation with the records of both the storage contractor and the intervention agency.The frequency and extent of stocktaking would depend on such factors asthe period for which the contractor had continuously held stocks, the rateof turnover and previous experience of his efficiency and reliability. Inso far as comprehersive stocktaking is not possible, recognised selectivechecking methods should be adopted, combined with a thorough reconciliation when stocks axe exhausted or at a low level.ιFurthermore, systematic checks should be applied when beef is being issued' from intervention stocks to ensure that there is no switching of lots to cover up deficiencies.The Committee also feels that the procedure adopted in some Member States,and referred to above, of making the cold stores legally liable under contract for the quantities delivered into store should be generally adopted.Stocks held by a Member State outside its ovm territoryA regluation should be adopted concerning public storage outside the terri­ tory of the Member State of intervention with a view to "Laying down detailed rule3 for its implementation. The new instrument should in particular specify: - 25 -– that storage in another Member State is authorised provided strict con­ ditions are observed end on the responsibility of the owner Member State}– that storage in a third country can only be authorized in cases of exceptional necessity (inspection and customs treatment of such stocks raise separate problems)}– the customs treatment to be applied to the transfer of meat and its storage abroad}– the detailed arrangements for stock control.D. Processing into preserved products of moat held by intervention agenciesThe Committee has emphasized the control difficulties caused by the decision to authorize the processing of certain intervention meat into preserved products.It further observes that the marketing of the preserved meat is extremely *slow. Out of a total production of 9° 000 metric tons , 294 m.t , had beensold by the French intervention agency and 150 m.t. by the Belgian agency up #to 31 December 1975• It was not until 30 January 1976 that a general decision was adopted on the marketing of the preserves ( l ), more than 18 months after processing operations were begun (Regulation 1295/74)* The Committee is not in a position to judge the conditons under which marketing is taking place.It requests, however, that as soon as all the necessary data are available (quantities sold and selling price) the Commission calculate the actual costof such an operation, taking into account the cost of manufacturing the preserved meat, storage costs (l8 months for the first batch) and the selling price.(l) Commission Regulation Ho 223/76 setting up a system linking imports of beef and veal products effected by way of protective measure- with the sale of preserved beef held by intervention agencies.. ' •••/•*• - 26 -E. ControlofoperationscarriedoutbyinterventionagenciesThe Committee considers it desirable for external checks of the intervention agencies to be strengthened in some Member States.F. Principle underlying the private storage aid systemThe granting of private storage aid was provided for "by Regulation no. 805/68 as one of the forms of publio intervention. Its purpose was to s+.pbilize prices by the withdrawal of fresh or refrigerated meat from the market. The mechanism consists of granting aid to operators, whether natural or legal persons* who at their own risk and expense store meat which they continue to own. These provisions were applied for the first time in January 1974*B. The rules applied1. Beneficiaries *Only natural or legal persons carrying on business iu cattle and meat who are officially registered in a Member State and have suitable storage fac­ ilities within the Community may receive^ aid.2. Meat in respect of which aid may be grantedPrivate storage aid may be granted only for products derived from animalsoriginating in the Community and slaughtered not more than 6 days previous­ ly^, with the exception of animals slaughtered in an emergency.^ By way of derogation certain regulations fixed this period at 10 days - 28 -The meat must alao satisfy certain health and veterinary requirements and must'not be unsuitable for storage and subséquent use.Amount of the aid and method Of fixing itThe aid may not in principle exceed an amount corresponding to the costs which would be incurred if storage were effected by the intervention agencies .The aid, which may be determined by means of a tendering procedure or "be pre-set, is' fixed per unit of weight of unboned meat and relates tothe weight ascertained on entry into store and before freezing.In the event of boning a rate of equivalence is fixed between the weight of the boned and the unboned meat. It is set at 77 % for carcases, half-carcases and compensated quarters and 70 % for forequarters.Obligations on thn benoficiaryThe aid is granted in accordance with the provisions of standard contracts concluded with the intervention agencies under which the storer undertakes- to place in store and to store the agreed quantity of the product in questionathisownriskandexpensewithinthespecified timelimits. (This obligation is regarded as fulfilled if not less than 90 % and not more than 110 % of the proposed quantity is placed in store and stored)- to advise the appropriate intervention agency of the day and place of entry into 6tore and the nature and quantity of the products to be stored ;- to forv/ard to the intervention agency the supporting documents in respect of the storage operations;- to store the products in easily identifiable lots;- to allow the intervention agency to check fulfilment of theseobligations at any time.When the contract is conclufed the storer must provide security. 5 •Conweqitpncgfi of nun-fulfilment of contracts 1 obligationsIf the storer does not fulfil his contractual obligations, both payment of the aid and release of the security will be affected. The general rule is that the storer acquires the right to payment of the aid and release of the security at the moment when the appropriate agency establishes that the obligations of the contracting party have been fulfilled .Among unfulfilled obligations, the failure to adhere to the quantities specified in the . contract has special consequents which v »re gradually defined and reinforced by the rules . At present' the following provision are applicable :(a) the right to payment of aid is acquired only if all the meat remained in storage during the entire storage period;(b) if the quantity placed in store is less than the quantity for which the contract was concluded and equals s- 90 % or more of that quantity, the amount of the aid i6 reduced; - less than 90 # of that quantity, the aid is not paid.(c) if less then 90 $ of the quantity specified in the contract is placed in store and stored within the specified deadlines, the security is forfeited in proportion to the missing amount except in the case of force majeure.- 29 -In the caue of cut and boned meat the percentage referred to above was fixed at 85 %6. Checks to be carried out by the intervention agenciesSApart from checking the technical characteristic ; of the meat as described in 2 above« the agency must check that the quantities andthe storage dates specified in the contract are adhered to by the storer . r i•/•I To the extent that operators are authorized to have the meat cut up or boned, the intervention agency is responsible for checking thatall the meat resulting from the boning or cutting operation was placed in store .The rules do not lay down any special, procedure for the check of boning operations .Spécial provisionsIn order to ensure some flexibility, several possibilities are providedfor changing the storage dates during the period of validity of the oontract .Firstly, the intervention agency or the Commission may decide to shorten or lengthen the storage period specified in the contract if the market situation BO reouires. * - V.In addition, several recent regulations have provided for the possibility of exporting the stored products before expiry of the storage period under certain conditions .IRREGULARITIBS AND CONTROL PROBLMS A. IrregularitiesTwo irregularities were brought to the knowledge of the Committee.1. The removal of products from storage before expiry of the period specif­ ied in "the .contract was discovered by an intervention agency whenexamining the supporting documents forwarded to it .\> The intervention agency considered that it was an error made in good faithby the operator and did not pay the aid for the goods which were removed t from storage . ' B.On the basis of supporting documents provided afterwards and in agreement with the Commission the aid was finally paid.Control problemsBecause of lack, of staff the intervention agencies are not ; 3.ways ableto carry out under satisfactory conditions the many checks which should be made at the various stages of the private storage operation, namely :- examination of carcases and quarters for health and veterinary purposes, (in particular checks to ensure that the animals were not slaughteredmore than 10 days previously) and weight checks?- in the event of boning, weight checks and supervision of the placing of cuts in store; '- verifying the presence of the stored meat during and on expiry of the storage period.The most serious difficulties arise in connection with placing in store and boning.• 1. Certain intervention agencies have drawn attention to difficulties inplanning inspection visits efficiently. They can only repond to notifi­cations from operators who wish to place products in store, by sendingofficials on the spot, on request, and to the extent that the necessary staff is available .2. The boning operation involves considerable labour for the intervention agency *- 31 -2. An operator placed goods in store without giving prior notice to the /intervention agency, which was not able to carry out the necessary checks Boning operations are carried, out frequently. It is recalled, for Example, that under Regulation no. 1860/75 on private storage offorequarters 78*000 m.t. were placed in store of which 45*000 nut.were in the form of boned cuts) with regard to Regulation no. 2711/75on private storage .of carcases, half-carcases and compensated quarters, of the 72.000 m.t. which were covered by contracts;32.000 m.t. were stored in the form of boned cuts and 11.600 m.t. as quarters with bones, according to the information available.Only by supervising each boning operation can it be ensured that all the meat resulting from the boning is actually placed in Btore.One intervention agency alBO found it difficult to check, with regard to the storing of boned, meat, that the product came from an animal which had been slaughtered less than 10 days previously*To apply the rules to the full tfye intervention agency needs therefore ' to mobilize a large staff, which is not always possible*SECTION III - RECOMMENDATIONS1. Observance of the purpose of the private storage policy... As in the case of intervention in general, in accordance with Article 5 of Regulation 805/68 the purpose of private storage is to withdraw from the market fresh or refrigerated meat in the form of carcases, half-carcases or quarters so as to prevent or mitigate a substantial fall in prices.The Committee noted that while, initially, priority in market support measures was generally given to public buying in, and private storage aid was fairly limited, the latter has been granted more frequently in recent years* * The Committee recommends that the private storage aid policy DO kept flexible so that it may be adjusted as quickly as possible to market developments and that it should not lead, through freqne it use, to the financing of the working stock of processing undertakings..»Boning authorizationGiven the purpose of private storage referred to above, the Commission sought to establish to what extent the boning operation is indispensable for achieving this purpose.It was found that the success of any private storage operation dependsupon authorization being given to operators to carry out boning. Boningof meat before freezing and placing in storage is economically justifiedfor processors who conclude private storage contracts . The boning operation , therefore , cannot be completely ruled , out .The Committee recommends, however :(a) that boning be carried out only when necessary on economic grounds. Where the amount of the aid is fixed by means of a tendering procedure authorization to carry out boning could be envisaged if the volume of QfferB received for storage of boned meat warrants it.(b) the boning operation should only be carried out in the presence of inspectors from the intervention agency and should be subject to the same rules as those governing boning of meat held by the intervention agency. - 34 -CHAPTER III - TRADE ARRANGEMENTSExcluding the system of monetary . and accession compensatory amounts, which will be dealt with inCHAPTER IVSECTION I - Summary of the regulationsA.
